column1: Lórinand was one of the many old names for the land usually called Lothlórien.
In a manuscript composed by J.R.R. Tolkien sometime after The Lord of the Rings
column2: Lórinand is said to be a Nandorin name
column3: meaning "valley of gold" (containing the "Elvish word meaning golden light").

column2: Christopher Tolkien notes that in a later manuscript the name Lórinand was reconceptualized as "a transformation
column3: after the introduction of the Mallorn
column4: of a yet older name Lothlórien#Names".
